text: it seems like you're in a retrospective
phase you're thinking about what you do
in the studio you're writing your
memoirs you're a self-conscious base I
guess it is it something changed for you
well you know for John for years people
have been asking to turn a camera on in
the recording studio to see what goes on
and I've always said no because frankly
I've not enjoyed the documentary
filmmaking process and and this time
around I said yes as long as I can bring
in my own guy and he can become a member
of the orchestra and then we can
actually catch you know the spirit of
the moment the magic moment i'm
interested in the past I'm talking about
it but you know we're making temporary
music and you know look into the future
as well and so this I'm hoping that this
film has has some of that in it you're
you Studios been out of New Orleans for
a while right what happened with that I
got in you I got out of New Orleans
before the storm and I have a studio in
Toronto and one in Los Angeles but I put
ten years into New Orleans and it was a
very prolific time you know mid bob
dylan's own mercy there my first record
a hiedi yellow moon for the Neville
Brothers and then hundreds of other
albums in my studio even in my absence
it was one of the great studios of
America but I think that was pretty much
the last chapter of that way of record
making you know I think the in these
contemporary times people are making
records in another sort of way people
are tempted by computers and it's much
more cost effective you can make you can
make a pretty good record in a closet
now it's fascinating to me and I I mean
I embrace that technology in the sense
that the people I'm working with
currently you know they everybody's got
that equipment now so but you know the
grand rooms and and the searching for
that right hallway that'll happen you
know the best sound for the guitar and
so on that that's kind of died out a
little bit only the gifted people at the
birth of rock and roll
you know they were only there were the
only ones that were allowed through the
gate and you you would have you would
sign somebody to a label because they
were already doing something on the
street that was fascinating so maybe
we're getting back to that I don't know
your guests as good as mine but I like
the idea the corner store you know a
little band if it takes a lot of energy
to get a record deal and get an agent
get a manager get people interested and
there's something sweet about building
your own audience and then saying okay
we're going to have our own site and
we're going to energy that we normally
put into getting a record deal we can
just put it into our own little corner
store so but I want to remind you that i
love record companies a lot of my
friends are in there and i'm going to
miss the smell of vinyl
